Stem: A student pushes a toy car from the left side, and another student pushes it from the right side with equal force. What will happen to the car?
Choices: A) It will move to the left, B) It will move to the right, C) It will stay in place, D) It will move up
Scenario Justification: Basic scenario of two students pushing a car. Familiar context but requires reasoning about balanced forces.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students must predict outcome of balanced forces. Selection-based.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of balanced forces. Application level — must reason about equal opposing forces.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (equal forces cause no movement). Implicit.
Key Recommendation: Add a data table showing different force combinations and outcomes. Ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Put these stages of a butterfly's life cycle in order.
Image/Diagram Description: Three images showing butterfly life cycle stages (1080x1080 each).
Choices: Technology Enhanced Item — drag and drop ordering of life cycle stages
Scenario Justification: Visual life cycle images provide context. Task is ordering known stages.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice beyond recall/sequencing. Ordering a memorized sequence.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of butterfly metamorphosis stages. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Replace with unfamiliar organism life cycle data and ask students to compare patterns across species.

Stem: How does the force between two magnets change as you move them farther apart?
Image/Diagram Description: Two images: magnets with force arrows (1080x1080), magnet diagram (850x822).
Choices: A) The force gets stronger, B) The force gets weaker, C) The force stays the same, D) The force disappears completely
Scenario Justification: Images show magnets but question is recall of magnetic force-distance relationship.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Pure recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how magnetic force changes with distance. Factual recall.
CCC Justification: No explicit CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide experimental data showing force measurements at different distances and ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: How does living in a herd help zebras survive?
Choices: A) Herds make it easier for predators to catch zebras, B) Herds help zebras find more food, C) Herds make it harder for predators to catch one zebra, D) Herds teach zebras how to run faster
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon or scenario. Asks about group behavior benefit as isolated fact.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of group living benefit.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of group behavior as survival advantage. Factual recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide observation data of predation success rates on solitary vs. herding animals and ask students to analyze the pattern.

Stem: A ball is rolling down a ramp. Which statement best predicts what will happen next?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of a ball on a ramp (612x391).
Choices: A) The ball will suddenly stop, B) The ball will roll faster as it goes down, C) The ball will roll slower as it goes down, D) The ball will change direction
Scenario Justification: Simple visual scenario of ball on ramp. Requires predicting motion.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Planning and Carrying Out Investigations' at basic level — predicting outcome of a physical scenario.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of gravity's effect on rolling objects. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (gravity causes acceleration down ramp).
Key Recommendation: Better with experimental data from multiple ramp angles. Add a data table and ask students to predict outcomes for untested conditions.

Stem: A brown rabbit has baby bunnies. Some bunnies are brown, and some are white. What does this tell us?
Choices: A) The white bunnies will turn brown as they grow, B) The bunnies' color is an inherited trait that can vary, C) The brown rabbit's fur got bleached by the sun, D) The brown rabbit adopted some white bunnies
Scenario Justification: Visual scenario with parent and offspring showing trait variation. Provides observable phenomenon.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students explain why offspring show variation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that inherited traits can vary between parent and offspring. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (variation in offspring traits is a pattern).
Key Recommendation: Good visual. Elevate by showing multiple litters with trait data and asking students to predict offspring patterns.

Stem: Scientists found seashell fossils on top of a mountain. What does this tell us about this place long ago?
Choices: A) Mountains used to be underwater, B) Seashells can grow on mountains, C) Birds carried seashells to the mountain top, D) The mountain formed around existing seashells
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario of fossil discovery in unexpected location. Requires reasoning about past environments.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students must reason from evidence (fossils) to conclusion about past conditions.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that fossils provide evidence of past environments. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (marine environment → marine fossils) and Stability and Change (environment changed over time).
Key Recommendation: Add more fossil evidence details (types, layers) and ask students to construct a more complete explanation.

Stem: What happens when you bring the north pole of one magnet close to the south pole of another magnet?
Choices: A) They push apart, B) They pull together, C) Nothing happens, D) They spin around
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of magnetic pole interactions.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall task.
DCI Justification: Tests basic magnet pole interaction. Pure recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Replace with experimental scenario showing magnet interactions at different orientations. Ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: What's the difference between weather and climate?
Choices: A) The weather changes day to day based on the position of the sun while climate stays the same all year, B) Weather is what's happening outside right now while climate is the pattern of weather over long periods of time, C) Weather is related to only one city while climate is related to the whole country, D) Weather is measured in temperature while climate is measured in rainfall and humidity
Scenario Justification: No scenario or data. Pure definition recall.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Vocabulary recall.
DCI Justification: Tests weather vs. climate definitions. Pure recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide weather data over different time periods and ask students to distinguish weather observations from climate patterns.

Stem: Why do some plants in the desert have very long roots?
Choices: A) To reach water deep underground, B) To share mineral resources with other plants through the root system, C) To absorb nutrients from mineral-rich deep soil layers, D) To store excess water in their roots for future use
Scenario Justification: Refers to desert plants but no specific organism or data. Basic environmental adaptation question.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of adaptation concept.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structural adaptation for survival. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (root structure helps access water).
Key Recommendation: Provide data comparing root lengths in different environments and ask students to identify the pattern and explain.

Stem: How is a plant's life cycle similar to an animal's life cycle?
Choices: A) Plants and animals both start as eggs, B) Plants and animals both need sunlight to grow, C) Plants and animals both grow and can reproduce, D) Plants and animals both build homes
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks for cross-domain comparison at recall level.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of shared life cycle characteristics.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that plants and animals share basic life cycle stages.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (shared life cycle stages) but not required for answer selection.
Key Recommendation: Show two specific life cycles side by side and ask students to identify patterns and explain differences.

Stem: A forest fire burns down many trees. How might this affect the animals living there?
Choices: A) The animals will have more places to hide, B) The animals will have less food and shelter, C) The animals will adapt to the new environment, D) The fire will only affect plant life not animals
Scenario Justification: Brief environmental change scenario. Requires reasoning about ecosystem connections.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students reason about cause and effect in ecosystems.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of organism-environment interdependence. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (fire → loss of habitat → animal impact) and Systems (ecosystem interconnections).
Key Recommendation: Provide before/after ecosystem data and ask students to predict specific impacts on different species.

Stem: Design a simple door latch using a magnet. Which of these would work best?
Choices: A) Put a magnet on the door and a metal plate on the wall, B) Put two magnets with the same poles facing each other, C) Put a magnet on the ceiling above the door, D) Put a magnet on the floor below the door
Scenario Justification: Engineering design scenario — students must apply magnet knowledge to solve a practical problem. Requires reasoning about which configuration achieves the goal.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — students evaluate design options for a magnetic latch. Selection-based but requires reasoning.
DCI Justification: Applies understanding of magnetic attraction between magnets and ferrous metals to a design context.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (magnet-metal plate creates holding force at door level).
Key Recommendation: Good engineering context. Elevate by providing criteria/constraints and asking students to evaluate multiple designs with trade-offs.

Stem: Twin kittens Shadow and Sunny were born with same black fur. Shadow spends time by sunny window and fur is turning brown; Sunny stays in shade and fur remains black. Which best explains why Shadow's fur is turning brown?
Choices: A) Shadow inherited genes that cause his fur to change color over time, B) Exposure to sunlight is affecting the color of Shadow's fur, C) Shadow's fur is turning brown because he is not eating enough nutritious food, D) Shadow is a different breed than Sunny leading to the change in fur color
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario with controlled variables (same genetics, same food, different sun exposure). Students must identify the environmental factor.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — students analyze a natural experiment with controlled variables and identify the causal factor.
DCI Justification: Requires distinguishing inherited traits from environmentally influenced traits using evidence from the scenario. Deep DCI engagement.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (sunlight exposure causes fur color change) and Patterns (correlation between sun exposure and color change).
Key Recommendation: Excellent question. Natural experiment with controlled variables. One of the best G3.11 items.

Stem: A neighborhood near a river that often overflows after heavy rain. Many homes on flat low land. Which solution would MOST help reduce the damage from flooding?
Choices: A) Plant flowers in front of each house, B) Add taller streetlights to help people see during rain, C) Build houses on raised platforms above the ground, D) Put more windows in the houses
Scenario Justification: Engineering scenario with real-world context — flood-prone neighborhood. Students evaluate solutions.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating which solution addresses the flood problem. Selection-based.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how engineering solutions can reduce weather-related hazards. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (elevation reduces flood damage) and Structure and Function (raised platforms address flooding).
Key Recommendation: Good real-world context. Elevate by providing flood data at different elevations and asking students to design and justify a solution.

Stem: How do fossils help scientists learn about animals that lived long ago?
Choices: A) Fossils of ancient animals have codes in them, B) Fossils show the shape and size of ancient animals, C) Scientists can learn about the speed of ancient animals, D) Fossils tell scientists what ancient animals' diet was
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks what fossils reveal as isolated fact.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of fossil information.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of what information fossils provide. Recall level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide images/descriptions of actual fossils and ask students to make inferences about the ancient organisms.

Stem: How does a penguin's thick layer of fat help it survive?
Choices: A) It helps the penguin float in water, B) It keeps the penguin warm in cold water, C) It makes the penguin look bigger to scare predators, D) It helps the penguin run faster on land
Scenario Justification: Visual of a penguin with question about adaptation function. Basic application.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of adaptation function.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structural adaptation for survival in cold environments.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (fat layer → insulation). Basic.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on fat thickness vs. water temperature across multiple species and ask students to identify the pattern.

Stem: Look at the picture of a child on a swing. What pattern do you see in the swing's motion?
Choices: A) The swing's motion changes based on the wind, B) The swing goes back and forth at a steady pace, C) The length of the swing chain affects how fast it swings, D) The swing goes to random heights as it goes back and forth
Scenario Justification: Visual scenario of swinging motion. Students must identify the pattern.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' at basic level — observing and identifying a motion pattern.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of regular/predictable motion patterns. Application level.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Patterns (identifying the regular back-and-forth pattern).
Key Recommendation: Provide actual swing motion data (height vs. time) and ask students to identify and describe the pattern.

Stem: Which of these animals typically lives in a large group?
Choices: A) Tigers, B) Penguins, C) Hummingbirds, D) Turtles
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of which animals are social.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall.
DCI Justification: Tests basic knowledge of animal group behavior. Pure recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide observation data about different animals and ask students to explain why some benefit from group living.

Stem: When a tree frog sits on a leaf, it's hard to see. How does this help the frog?
Choices: A) It helps the frog get food from the leaf, B) It helps the frog hide from predators, C) It helps the frog get more sunlight, D) It helps the frog swim better
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario of frog camouflage. Requires basic reasoning about adaptation function.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engagement. Recall of camouflage function.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of camouflage as survival adaptation. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function implicitly but not required.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on predation rates for different frog colorations in various environments and ask students to analyze.

Stem: Look at these pictures of beaks from different bird species. How do their shapes help the birds?
Choices: A) The different shapes help birds make different sounds, B) The different shapes help birds eat different types of food, C) The different shapes help birds fly faster, D) The different shapes are for the different plants they pollinate
Scenario Justification: Visual data showing beak diversity. Students must connect form to function.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' at basic level — interpreting visual evidence of structural diversity.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structure-function relationship in adaptations.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (beak shape → food type). Direct CCC link.
Key Recommendation: Good visual. Add specific food type data for each bird and ask students to match beaks to food types using evidence.

Stem: What might happen to polar bears if the Arctic suddenly gets warmer?
Choices: A) Their fur will adapt and become shorter with the weather, B) They might have trouble finding food and surviving, C) They will have to find different places to live during the day and night, D) They will go in the water more frequently to stay cool
Scenario Justification: Brief scenario about environmental change. Requires reasoning about impact on organisms.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — predicting environmental change effects on organisms.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how environmental changes affect organisms' survival.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (warming → habitat loss → survival difficulty).
Key Recommendation: Provide Arctic ice extent data over time and polar bear population data. Ask students to analyze the relationship.

Stem: How do the spines on a cactus help it survive in the desert?
Choices: A) They provide shade to lower the cactus's temperature, B) They protect the cactus from animals that might eat it, C) They collect water from morning dew for hydration, D) They help the cactus absorb more sunlight for growth
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Asks about cactus spine function as isolated fact.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of adaptation function.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structural adaptation for protection. Recall level.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function implicitly but no reasoning required.
Key Recommendation: Show desert ecosystem data with herbivore-plant interactions and ask students to explain how spines provide survival advantage.

Stem: Mrs. Thompson's class scenario: Sunnyvale wants to improve weather forecasting. Which method should scientists use to learn about the town's weather patterns effectively?
Choices: A) By collecting and analyzing data from weather instruments like thermometers barometers wind vanes and rain gauges over long periods, B) By asking residents to recall weather from childhood, C) By making predictions based on how the sky looks each morning, D) By watching documentaries on severe weather
Scenario Justification: Rich classroom scenario with real-world context. Students must evaluate scientific methods for weather data collection.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Planning and Carrying Out Investigations' — evaluating which data collection method is most reliable/scientific.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of systematic weather data collection vs. informal methods.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (collecting data over time reveals patterns) and Stability and Change.
Key Recommendation: Good scenario. Elevate by providing sample weather data from different collection methods and asking students to evaluate which produces more reliable patterns.

Stem: Which of the following are ways people can build houses to reduce the impact of severe weather like storms and floods? Select all that apply.
Choices: A) Using strong materials that can withstand heavy winds, B) Building houses with windows on all sides to see approaching storms, C) Elevating houses on stilts to prevent flooding, D) Installing lightning rods on rooftops, E) Painting houses dark colors to absorb heat
Scenario Justification: Lists engineering solutions without a specific scenario context. Students evaluate which are effective.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating multiple potential solutions. Multi-select adds complexity.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of weather hazard mitigation through engineering. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (design features → weather protection).
Key Recommendation: Add a specific scenario with constraints and ask students to prioritize solutions with justification.

Stem: Marina studies ocean ecosystems. Ocean temperature has been slowly rising. How might this affect ocean animals?
Choices: A) Animals will quickly evolve new body structures, B) Some animals might gradually move to new areas where temperature is more suitable potentially disrupting existing ecosystems, C) All cold-water species will die off immediately, D) Temperature change won't affect marine animals because they can control body temperature
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario about ocean warming with gradual environmental change. Students must reason about ecological impacts.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about cascading effects of environmental change on ecosystems.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding ecosystem dynamics and how gradual environmental changes affect organisms. Goes beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (warming → migration → ecosystem disruption) and Stability and Change.
Key Recommendation: Provide actual ocean temperature and species distribution data and ask students to analyze trends and predict outcomes.

Stem: Dr. Lee discovers tropical plant fossils in Antarctica. What is the most reasonable conclusion?
Choices: A) Plants developed special adaptations to survive in extremely cold climates, B) Ancient explorers brought tropical plants to Antarctica, C) The climate in Antarctica was likely much warmer in the past supporting the idea that Earth's climate can change dramatically, D) Tropical plant seeds were carried to Antarctica by wind or ocean currents
Scenario Justification: Rich scientific discovery scenario with real-world context. Students must reason from fossil evidence to conclusion about climate change.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations from Evidence' — students must analyze fossil evidence and construct a reasonable conclusion. Genuine reasoning required.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of fossils as evidence of past environments and climate change. Deep DCI engagement.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (past warm climate → tropical plants) and Stability and Change (climate changed over millions of years). Strong CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Excellent question. Real scientific scenario requiring evidence-based reasoning. One of the best G3.11 items.

Stem: Liam and Sophia study animals in a wetland habitat. Which animals are likely to survive well in a wetland? Select all that apply.
Choices: A) Frogs that lay eggs in water and have tadpoles, B) Beavers that build dams in streams, C) Foxes that hunt small animals in underground dens, D) Mallard ducks with webbed feet that feed on aquatic plants, E) Prairie dogs that live in grasslands
Scenario Justification: Rich wetland habitat scenario with specific organism descriptions. Students must match adaptations to environment.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students evaluate organism trait descriptions against habitat requirements. Multi-select requires evaluating each option independently.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of organism-environment fit using specific trait data. Deep reasoning about adaptations.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (organism traits → habitat suitability) and Patterns.
Key Recommendation: Strong multi-select question with rich scenario. Students must evaluate each organism's traits against wetland requirements.

Stem: Bar graph showing average monthly temperatures for a city. Based on the graph which statement best describes the climate?
Image/Diagram Description: Bar graph of average monthly temperatures (1600x990).
Choices: A) Tropical climate with consistently high temperatures, B) Temperate climate with warm summers and cold winters, C) Desert because very hot day and cold night, D) Climate is changing rapidly as evidenced by temperature fluctuations
Scenario Justification: Real climate data in graph form. Students must interpret data to characterize climate.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students must read a bar graph and identify the climate pattern from monthly temperature data.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of climate patterns (seasonal variation) to real data. Goes beyond recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (seasonal temperature pattern reveals climate type). Direct CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Good data-driven climate analysis. Students interpret real graphical data to draw conclusions.

Stem: Which combination of actions would be most effective in preparing for and mitigating the effects of a hurricane?
Choices: A) Stocking up on non-perishable food boarding up windows and evacuating low-lying areas if advised, B) Turning off electricity filling bathtubs and staying outdoors to monitor storm, C) Opening windows to equalize air pressure storing valuables in basement and tying down furniture with light rope, D) Covering roof with plastic tarp stockpiling batteries and planning to use generator indoors
Scenario Justification: Evaluates hurricane preparedness strategies. Real-world application but no specific data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating which combination of actions is most effective. Requires evaluating trade-offs.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of weather hazard preparedness. Application level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (preparedness actions → reduced hurricane impact).
Key Recommendation: Good real-world topic. Provide a specific hurricane scenario with constraints and ask students to design a preparedness plan with justification.
